review_title: Air of enthusiasm as they are ever growing it seems, lots of opportunity for vertical mobility
pros: The people. There are a lot of them in every major city. That means that there's almost certainly someone like you already working for the company and they are loving it. When joining (or even prior) you should try and find that person. Maybe you have an IT background or law or business. Finding them will be a lot easier because there will be a lot of them around. The work. Accenture is very forward-thinking. To stay on top of the innovation game, you have to have people willing to think analytically and solve problems. Not necessarily problems no-one has solved before. Innovation doesn't mean reinventing the wheel every couple months. Many times it's learning about and applying a known method or practice to a business or area of life that has never benefited from that critical thought. The opportunity. Internally there is a treasure-trove of content to learn and consume. They sell themselves as being the biggest online university world-wide. They might be. With a company this large there is always something going on, whether grad events engaging with universities or schools, community events like BBQs or fun runs, mentoring opportunities, or working groups of just some like-minded energetic people that get together to do something fun on the side. One last thing. If you perform, you are rewarded. Some people go from graduate to manager in as little as 3 years (rare). But there is certainly vertical mobility if you have the drive, the passion and the capacity.
cons: As a grad, you are a pawn to some. Like molding clay with no background or past that can be crafted into anything. Molding clay has no desire to be a pot or a cup. It does as it is told by the crafter. Not everyone sees you like this. Some fight for you to get the roles you want. But alas. There are good and bad apples everywhere in life. This is no different. The overtime time. What overtime pay? Not sure what that is... But really though it's rather abysmal. The only consolation is that if you get work that you really do love then overtime isn't going to feel like it so much. Not a good excuse but there isn't much else in it's defense.
